message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone measured in this patient's urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). hCG is responsible for the maintenance of the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone to support the early pregnancy. It does not inhibit ovulation or breast tissue development, and its effect on preterm uterine contractions is still uncertain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone that is measured in urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is secreted by the placenta. It maintains the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone necessary for the maintenance of the pregnancy. It does not inhibit ovulation, develop breast tissue or inhibit preterm uterine contractions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone that was measured in the patient's urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is responsible for the maintenance of the corpus luteum in the ovary, which in turn produces progesterone to support the developing pregnancy. hCG does not directly inhibit ovulation, develop breast tissue, or inhibit preterm uterine contractions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone that is measured in the patient's urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which maintains the corpus luteum in the ovary during the early stages of pregnancy. This is important for the production of progesterone, which is necessary for the maintenance of the pregnancy. Inhibition of ovulation and development of breast tissue are primarily controlled by estrogen and progesterone. Inhibition of preterm uterine contractions is primarily controlled by progesterone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone measured in urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), which is responsible for maintenance of the corpus luteum in the ovary to continue producing progesterone to support the pregnancy. It does not inhibit ovulation, develop breast tissue, or inhibit preterm uterine contractions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone measured in the urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which maintains the corpus luteum in the ovary, allowing for the production of progesterone to support the early pregnancy. Inhibition of ovulation is primarily attributed to estrogen and progesterone. Development of breast tissue is primarily attributed to estrogen. Inhibition of preterm uterine contractions is primarily attributed to progesterone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone measured in urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is responsible for the maintenance of the corpus luteum during the first trimester of pregnancy. It is not directly responsible for the other options listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone that is measured in urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is responsible for maintaining the corpus luteum in the ovary, which in turn produces progesterone to support the early pregnancy. hCG does not directly inhibit ovulation, develop breast tissue, or inhibit preterm uterine contractions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone that is measured in urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). hCG maintains the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone that supports the early pregnancy. Option B is incorrect because hCG does not inhibit ovulation, but rather stimulates the corpus luteum to continue producing progesterone. Option C is incorrect because the development of breast tissue is primarily under the control of estrogen and prolactin. Option D is incorrect because progesterone, not hCG, is responsible for inhibiting preterm uterine contractions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hormone measured in urine to detect pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which maintains the corpus luteum in the ovary during the first trimester of pregnancy to produce progesterone. This ensures that the endometrium is maintained to support the developing fetus. Option B is incorrect because hCG does not inhibit ovulation but actually stimulates the corpus luteum to produce progesterone. Option C is incorrect because development of breast tissue is mainly regulated by estrogen, not hCG. Option D is incorrect because hCG does not inhibit preterm uterine contractions.
